title: Larry Brinson
text:
Larry Sylvesta Brinson (born June 6, 1954) is a former American <a href="college%20football">college football</a> coach and a former <a href="American%20football">football</a> <a href="running%20back">running back</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> for the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> and <a href="Seattle%20Seahawks">Seattle Seahawks</a>. He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Florida">University of Florida</a>.
Early years.
Brinson was born in <a href="Opa-locka%2C%20Florida">Opa-locka, Florida</a> in 1954. He attended <a href="Miami%20Northwestern%20Senior%20High%20School">Miami Northwestern Senior High School</a>, where he played football and also lettered in <a href="track%20and%20field">track</a>.
College career.
Brinson accepted a football scholarship from the <a href="University%20of%20Florida">University of Florida</a> in Gainesville, Florida, where he played for coach <a href="Doug%20Dickey">Doug Dickey</a>'s <a href="Florida%20Gators%20football">Florida Gators football</a> team from <a href="1973%20Florida%20Gators%20football%20team">1973</a> to <a href="1976%20Florida%20Gators%20football%20team">1976</a>. In 1973, he became the starter at <a href="running%20back">running back</a> after <a href="Nat%20Moore">Nat Moore</a> sprained his foot and fractured his left tibia, but would lose playing time with a dislocated wrist that kept him out until the month of November.
He was named the starter at <a href="Halfback%20%28American%20football%29">right halfback</a> as a sophomore, but suffered a <a href="hip%20pointer">hip pointer</a> injury and was relegated to a reserve role behind <a href="Tony%20Green%20%28American%20football%29">Tony Green</a>, while rushing for 418 yards.
He would regain the starter position as a senior, spending time at <a href="Halfback%20%28American%20football%29">right halfback</a> and <a href="Fullback%20%28American%20football%29">fullback</a>, finishing his college career with 1,105 rushing yards on 240 carries, a 4.9 yards per carry average and 9 <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>s. He played in four <a href="bowl%20game">bowl game</a>s and graduated with a bachelor's degree
Professional career.
Dallas Cowboys.
Brinson was signed as an <a href="undrafted%20free%20agent">undrafted free agent</a> by the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> after the <a href="1977%20NFL%20Draft">1977 NFL Draft</a> and made the team despite fracturing a cheekbone during training camp. As a rookie, he was the regular kickoff returner, tying for eighth in the NFC with 17 returns for an average of 24.1 yards.
In <a href="1978%20NFL%20season">1978</a>, he was limited with a groin injury and had no pre-season action. He was waived on August 28, before being re-signed in October after <a href="Doug%20Dennison">Doug Dennison</a> was injured. He appeared in 10 games and shared the kickoff return duties with <a href="Butch%20Johnson%20%28American%20football%29">Butch Johnson</a>. His best game came in the 37–10 win against the <a href="Washington%20Redskins">Washington Redskins</a>, where he ran for 51 yards on 4 carries, including a 39-yard <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a> run.
In <a href="1979%20NFL%20season">1979</a>, he suffered a dislocated left shoulder on his first carry of the season opener against the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Cardinals%20%28NFL%29">St. Louis Cardinals</a>. He missed the next 2 games and only had 14 carries for 48 yards during the season.
In <a href="1980%20NFL%20season">1980</a>, he was switched from <a href="Fullback%20%28American%20football%29">fullback</a> to <a href="Halfback%20%28American%20football%29">halfback</a> in training camp. He was released on September first. During his time with the Cowboys he was a backup <a href="Fullback%20%28American%20football%29">fullback</a> and <a href="kickoff%20returner">kickoff returner</a>, including <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XII">Super Bowl XII</a> and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XIII">Super Bowl XIII</a>.
Seattle Seahawks.
On September 3, <a href="1980%20NFL%20season">1980</a>, Brinson was claimed off waivers by the <a href="Seattle%20Seahawks">Seattle Seahawks</a>. He was seldom used, playing in 7 games and rushing for 57 yards on 16 carries. He was placed on the <a href="injured%20reserve%20list">injured reserve list</a> on August 17, <a href="1981%20NFL%20season">1981</a>.
Coaching career.
After retiring from the NFL, Brinson became the running backs coach for head coach <a href="Ken%20Hatfield">Ken Hatfield</a> at the <a href="United%20States%20Air%20Force%20Academy">U.S. Air Force Academy</a> in Colorado Springs, Colorado in 1983. Hatfield was a Florida Gators assistant coach when Brinson was a Gators running back. Hatfield's offensive scheme was run-oriented, emphasizing Brinson's area of expertise. 
Brinson moved with Hatfield and became the running backs coach for the <a href="Arkansas%20Razorbacks%20football">Arkansas Razorbacks</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Arkansas">University of Arkansas</a> in Fayetteville, Arkansas (1984–89), the <a href="Clemson%20Tigers%20football">Clemson Tigers</a> at <a href="Clemson%20University">Clemson University</a> in Clemson, South Carolina (1990–93) and the <a href="Rice%20Owls%20football">Rice Owls</a> at <a href="Rice%20University">Rice University</a> in Houston, Texas (1994–2005). In 2007, Brinson joined the <a href="Kentucky%20Wildcats%20football">Kentucky Wildcats</a> coaching staff at the University of Kentucky in Lexington, Kentucky, also as running backs coach, and stayed in that position through the 2010 season.
Personal life.
Brinson has two daughters and a son.
